title: Reinforced Concrete Beam Flexural Design
problem: Design a rectangular reinforced concrete beam to span 22 feet and support a service dead load of 1.2 kip/ft and service live load of 1.8 kip/ft. Use $f'_c = 5,000$ psi and Grade 60 reinforcement. Beam width is limited to 14 inches.
required: Determine beam depth and required reinforcement area.

solution_steps.title: Estimate Effective Depth
solution_steps.content:
Using $\rho = 0.0107$ (tension-controlled limit):

$$d = \sqrt{\frac{M_u}{0.9\rho b(1 - 0.59\rho f_y/f'_c)}} = 20.5 \text{ in}$$

Use $h = 24$ in, $d = 21.5$ in

solution_steps.title: Calculate Required Steel Area
solution_steps.content:
Using the quadratic equation:

$$A_s = \frac{M_u}{\phi f_y (d - a/2)}$$

Solving iteratively: $A_s = 2.89 \text{ in}^2$

solution_steps.title: Check Tension-Controlled Behavior
solution_steps.content:
$$a = \frac{A_s f_y}{0.85 f'_c b} = \frac{2.89 \times 60}{0.85 \times 5 \times 14} = 2.91 \text{ in}$$

$$c = a/\beta_1 = 2.91/0.80 = 3.64 \text{ in}$$

$$\varepsilon_t = 0.003(d-c)/c = 0.0147 > 0.005$$ ✓

Section is tension-controlled.

solution_steps.title: Check Minimum Reinforcement
solution_steps.content:
$$A_{s,min} = \max(3\sqrt{f'_c}/f_y \times bd, 200/f_y \times bd) = 1.07 \text{ in}^2$$

$$A_s = 2.89 \text{ in}^2 > 1.07 \text{ in}^2$$ ✓

final_answer: Use a **14 in × 24 in beam** with **3-#9 bars** ($A_s = 3.00 \text{ in}^2$). The effective depth $d = 21.5$ in provides a tension-controlled section.

title: Steel Beam Design with Lateral-Torsional Buckling
problem: A W21×57 beam (A992 steel) spans 30 feet and is laterally braced only at the supports and midspan ($L_b = 15$ ft). Determine the available flexural strength. The beam supports a uniform load producing a maximum moment of 280 kip-ft.
required: Determine available flexural strength and check adequacy.

solution_steps.title: Determine Section Properties
solution_steps.content:
From AISC Manual:

- $Z_x = 129$ in³
- $S_x = 117$ in³
- $L_p = 8.25$ ft
- $L_r = 23.9$ ft
- $M_p = F_y Z_x = 50 \times 129/12 = 537.5$ kip-ft

solution_steps.title: Check Lateral-Torsional Buckling Limit
solution_steps.content:
Since $L_p = 8.25$ ft $< L_b = 15$ ft $< L_r = 23.9$ ft:

**Inelastic LTB governs**

solution_steps.title: Calculate Nominal Flexural Strength
solution_steps.content:
For inelastic LTB:

$$M_n = C_b\left[M_p - (M_p - 0.7F_y S_x)\left(\frac{L_b - L_p}{L_r - L_p}\right)\right] \leq M_p$$

With $C_b = 1.30$ (uniform load with midspan brace):

$$M_n = 1.30\left[537.5 - (537.5 - 273)\left(\frac{15 - 8.25}{23.9 - 8.25}\right)\right]$$

$$M_n = 1.30[537.5 - 264.5 \times 0.43] = 1.30 \times 424 = 551 \text{ kip-ft}$$

But $M_n \leq M_p = 537.5$ kip-ft, so $M_n = 537.5$ kip-ft

solution_steps.title: Calculate Available Strength
solution_steps.content:
**LRFD:**
$$\phi_b M_n = 0.90 \times 537.5 = 484 \text{ kip-ft}$$

**ASD:**
$$M_n/\Omega_b = 537.5/1.67 = 322 \text{ kip-ft}$$

solution_steps.title: Check Adequacy
solution_steps.content:
$$\phi_b M_n = 484 \text{ kip-ft} > M_u = 280 \text{ kip-ft}$$ ✓

**Beam is adequate.**

final_answer: Available flexural strength: $\phi_b M_n = 484$ kip-ft (LRFD). The beam is adequate for $M_u = 280$ kip-ft with a utilization ratio of 58%.

title: Shallow Foundation Bearing Capacity
problem: A rectangular spread footing 8 ft × 12 ft is founded at a depth of 4 ft in dense sand with friction angle $\phi' = 36°$, unit weight $\gamma = 125$ pcf, and cohesion $c' = 0$. Groundwater is at 15 ft depth. Calculate the nominal bearing capacity using the general bearing capacity equation.
given: Groundwater at 15 ft depth (below footing base)

solution_steps.title: Apply General Bearing Capacity Equation
solution_steps.content:
Since $c' = 0$:

$$q_n = q N_q s_q d_q + 0.5 \gamma B N_\gamma s_\gamma d_\gamma$$

Where $q = \gamma D_f = 125 \times 4 = 500$ psf

$$q_n = 500 \times 37.75 \times 1.48 \times 1.25 + 0.5 \times 125 \times 8 \times 56.31 \times 0.73 \times 1.0$$

$$q_n = 34,956 + 205,536 = 240,492 \text{ psf} \approx 240 \text{ ksf}$$

final_answer: The nominal bearing capacity is approximately $q_n = 240$ ksf. For LRFD, factored resistance $q_R = \phi q_n = 0.45 \times 240 = 108$ ksf.

title: Concrete Pile Axial Capacity
problem: A 16-inch diameter concrete-filled steel pipe pile is driven 45 ft into layered soil. Upper 20 ft is soft clay with $S_u = 800$ psf. Lower 25 ft is medium-dense sand with $\phi' = 34°$, $\gamma = 122$ pcf. Calculate the nominal axial compressive resistance using the $\alpha$-method for clay and Nordlund method for sand.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Shaft Resistance in Clay
solution_steps.content:
Using $\alpha$-method:

For $S_u = 800$ psf: $\alpha = 0.95$

$$f_s = \alpha \times S_u = 0.95 \times 800 = 760 \text{ psf}$$

$$A_s = \pi \times \frac{16}{12} \times 20 = 83.78 \text{ ft}^2$$

$$R_{s,clay} = 760 \times 83.78 = 63,673 \text{ lb} = 63.7 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Shaft Resistance in Sand
solution_steps.content:
Using Nordlund method with $\delta = 0.7\phi' = 23.8°$, $K_\delta = 1.2$:

Average effective stress: $\sigma'_v = 3,725$ psf

$$f_s = K_\delta \times \sigma'_v \times \frac{\sin(\phi' + \delta)}{\cos\delta} = 4,150 \text{ psf}$$

$$R_{s,sand} = 4,150 \times 104.7 = 434.5 \text{ kips}$$

solution_steps.title: Calculate Tip Resistance
solution_steps.content:
For sand with $\phi' = 34°$:

$$q_p = N_q \times \sigma'_{v,tip} = 30 \times 5,250 = 157,500 \text{ psf}$$

$$A_p = \frac{\pi \times (16/12)^2}{4} = 1.40 \text{ ft}^2$$

$$R_p = 157,500 \times 1.40 = 220.5 \text{ kips}$$

final_answer: The nominal axial compressive resistance is $R_n = 719$ kips. For LRFD, $R_R = \phi R_n = 0.45 \times 719 = 323$ kips.

title: Concrete Mix Design - Strength Requirements
problem: A structural engineer needs to specify a concrete mix for an interior beam in a building. The beam requires $f'_c = 5,000$ psi at 28 days. The structure is exposed to freeze-thaw cycles but not deicing chemicals. Determine the required average compressive strength $f'_{cr}$ if the standard deviation from 30 consecutive tests is $s = 650$ psi.
given: Exposure: Freeze-thaw cycles, no deicing chemicals
required: Calculate the required average compressive strength $f'_{cr}$ for the concrete mix.

solution_steps.title: Determine Modification Factor
solution_steps.content: Per ACI 318-19 Table 26.4.3.1(a), for 30 consecutive tests, modification factor = 1.0 (no modification needed).

solution_steps.title: Determine Governing Value
solution_steps.content:
The required average strength is the larger of the two values:
$$f'_{cr} = 6,015 \text{ psi}$$

final_answer: The required average compressive strength is $f'_{cr} = 6,015$ psi for the concrete mix design.

title: Steel Material Properties Verification
problem: A tension coupon test was performed on a sample from a steel shipment labeled as A992 Grade 50. The test specimen had a yield strength of 52 ksi and ultimate tensile strength of 70 ksi. Determine if the material meets the A992 specification requirements.
given: A992 Specification: $F_y = 50-65$ ksi min, $F_u = 65$ ksi min
required: Verify if the steel meets A992 specification requirements.

solution_steps.title: Check Yield Strength Requirements
solution_steps.content:
A992 specification requires:
- Minimum yield strength: 50 ksi
- Maximum yield strength: 65 ksi

Measured: $F_y = 52$ ksi

$$50 \text{ ksi} \leq 52 \text{ ksi} \leq 65 \text{ ksi}$$ ✓

solution_steps.title: Check Tensile Strength Requirements
solution_steps.content:
A992 specification requires minimum tensile strength: 65 ksi

Measured: $F_u = 70$ ksi

$$70 \text{ ksi} > 65 \text{ ksi}$$ ✓

solution_steps.title: Check Yield-to-Tensile Ratio
solution_steps.content:
A992 specification requires $F_y/F_u \leq 0.85$ for seismic applications:

$$\frac{52}{70} = 0.74 < 0.85$$ ✓

final_answer: The steel sample **meets** all A992 Grade 50 specification requirements. Yield strength = 52 ksi, tensile strength = 70 ksi, and yield-to-tensile ratio = 0.74.

title: Soil Classification Using USCS
problem: A soil sample has the following properties: 15% retained on No. 4 sieve, 35% retained on No. 200 sieve, liquid limit LL = 42%, and plasticity index PI = 18%. Classify the soil using the Unified Soil Classification System (USCS).

solution_steps.title: Determine Grain Size Distribution
solution_steps.content:
Percent passing No. 4 sieve: $100 - 15 = 85\%$

Percent passing No. 200 sieve: $100 - 35 = 65\%$

Since > 50% passes No. 200 sieve, this is a **fine-grained soil** (silt or clay).

solution_steps.title: Check Liquid Limit
solution_steps.content:
LL = 42%

Since LL > 50%, this is a **high plasticity** soil.

High plasticity soils have LL > 50%, low plasticity soils have LL < 50%.

solution_steps.title: Plot on Plasticity Chart
solution_steps.content:
A-line equation: $PI = 0.73(LL - 20) = 0.73(42 - 20) = 16.1\%$

Measured PI = 18% > 16.1%

The point plots **above the A-line**, indicating clay.

solution_steps.title: Assign USCS Symbol
solution_steps.content:
Since LL = 42% is between 50% and the A-line intercept, and PI plots above A-line:

Classification: **CL** (Lean Clay) or **CH** (Fat Clay)

With LL = 42% < 50%, the soil is classified as **CL** (Lean Clay of low to medium plasticity).

final_answer: The soil is classified as **CL** (Lean Clay) using the Unified Soil Classification System. It is a fine-grained soil with low to medium plasticity.

title: Clay Brick Compressive Strength Testing
problem: Five clay brick samples were tested for compressive strength with results: 8,500 psi, 9,200 psi, 8,800 psi, 9,500 psi, and 8,700 psi. Determine if the bricks meet the minimum requirements for Grade SW (Severe Weathering) brick per ASTM C62.
given: Grade SW minimum: 3,000 psi individual, 4,500 psi average
required: Verify if bricks meet Grade SW requirements.

solution_steps.title: Check Individual Minimum
solution_steps.content:
Minimum individual value = 8,500 psi

Grade SW requirement: 3,000 psi minimum individual

$$8,500 > 3,000$$ ✓

solution_steps.title: Check Average Requirement
solution_steps.content:
Grade SW requirement: 4,500 psi average minimum

$$8,940 > 4,500$$ ✓

final_answer: The bricks **meet** Grade SW requirements. Average strength = 8,940 psi (exceeds 4,500 psi minimum) and minimum individual = 8,500 psi (exceeds 3,000 psi minimum).

title: Timber Moisture Content and Grading
problem: A Douglas Fir-Larch No. 2 beam (6×12 nominal) will be used in a covered bridge structure. The design moisture content is 19%. Determine the appropriate adjustment factors for moisture content.
required: Determine moisture content adjustment factors for bending and compression.

solution_steps.title: Determine Size Category
solution_steps.content:
A 6×12 has actual dimensions of 5.5" × 11.5"

Thickness = 5.5" < 4" in thickness? No, so this is a **Beams and Stringers** (B&S) size.

Actually, for 5.5" thick, this is classified as **Dimension Lumber** since it is 2" to 4" thick (5.5" is actually thicker).

Correct classification: This is a **Timber** since minimum dimension > 5".

solution_steps.title: Determine Moisture Condition
solution_steps.content:
Per NDS, for moisture content $\leq 19\%$, the wood is considered "dry" and no wet service factor reduction is needed.

For moisture content $> 19\%$, wet service factors apply:
- $C_M$ for bending: 0.85
- $C_M$ for compression: 0.80

solution_steps.title: Apply Adjustment Factors
solution_steps.content:
Since design MC = 19% (at the threshold):

If MC will remain at or below 19% in service:
- $C_M = 1.0$ (no reduction)

If MC may exceed 19% in service:
- $C_M = 0.85$ for bending
- $C_M = 0.80$ for compression

final_answer: For MC = 19%, the moisture content is at the threshold. If the wood will remain dry (MC ≤ 19%) in service, $C_M = 1.0$. If wet conditions are expected, use $C_M = 0.85$ for bending and $C_M = 0.80$ for compression.

title: Concrete Cylinder Strength Testing - Acceptance
problem: A concrete pour for a building floor slab specified $f'_c = 4,000$ psi. Three sets of cylinders were tested at 28 days with the following average strengths: Set 1 = 3,950 psi, Set 2 = 3,800 psi, Set 3 = 4,100 psi. Determine if the concrete meets the acceptance criteria per ACI 318-19.
required: Evaluate concrete acceptance per ACI 318-19 criteria.

solution_steps.title: Calculate Overall Average
solution_steps.content: Average of all tests: $\frac{3,950 + 3,800 + 4,100}{3} = 3,950$ psi

solution_steps.title: Check ACI Acceptance Criteria
solution_steps.content:
Per ACI 318-19 Section 26.12.3.1, concrete is acceptable if:

1. Every individual test average ≥ $f'_c - 500$ psi
   - Check: $3,800 \geq 4,000 - 500 = 3,500$ psi ✓

2. Average of all tests ≥ $f'_c$
   - Check: $3,950 \geq 4,000$ psi ✗ (3,950 < 4,000)

solution_steps.title: Determine Acceptance
solution_steps.content:
The concrete **FAILS** the acceptance criteria because the average of all tests (3,950 psi) is less than the specified strength (4,000 psi).

Per ACI 318-19, additional investigation or testing may be required.

final_answer: The concrete **does not meet** acceptance criteria. While all individual tests exceed $f'_c - 500 = 3,500$ psi, the overall average of 3,950 psi is below $f'_c = 4,000$ psi. Core testing or structural evaluation may be required.
